node.title: A trip to Sydney’s Royal Botanic Garden
node.excerpt: Specifically, the succulent garden, which was among the largest by area of the “themed” sections.  Danger Garden, this is for you. The entire succulent garden is in raised beds and large planters made of what appears to be Cor-Ten steel or similar. That dark rusty color of course does wonders for the lovely silvery blues […]

node.title: Backyard pain points

node.title: Wednesday Vignette: Neighbors
node.excerpt: Last year I sent a tromboncino squash vine right over this fence into my neighbors’ backyard.  Yes, on purpose.  This year, the luffas got into their lilac and made three or four fruits (technically berries! but let’s not get into that now).  At one point, he said, through the fence because he knew I was […]

node.title: Fall Planting: Part 1
node.excerpt: (Of however many parts it takes) This is my third year gardening at my current house. node.title: The Indoor Garden, 2017-18
node.excerpt: This year’s overwintering area has experienced a revamp/relocation.  In previous years, I’ve simply moved tropical houseplants outdoors (where possible) for their summer vacations and then put them back in my house wherever they can fit — hopefully with a reasonable amount of window-light.  But this year, I decided to kick it up a notch.  Yes, […]

node.title: Wednesday Vignette: Thank you, Lavender Who Came With The House
node.excerpt: I love this plant.  Especially this time of year, because it makes all the other things look fantastic.       This is one of a handful of plants I am really happy to have inherited with this house.  It reminds me that I don’t need to worry all that much about where I plant […]

node.title: Cousin Itt
node.excerpt: I have two specimen trees that were planted right about when my house was built (1968).  They’re in absolutely primo spots in the front yard, visible to all, seen and felt multiple times daily by us and everyone who drives by.  They influence my gardening decisions and options very heavily in the front yard.  They […]

node.title: Australia, June 2017
node.excerpt: Years ago if you’d asked me, “What’s your favorite garden aesthetic?” I probably would have said something about lush, tropicalesque, big foliage, dramatic plants, etc.  Over the course of the last couple years that has all changed, in part because of lovely things I’ve seen on the internet, three years of experience and observation in […]
